results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response:
To calculate the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market, we use valuation techniques to maximise the use of observable market data. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3.
Specific valuation techniques used to value financial instruments mainly include: • Dealer quotes for similar instruments; and • The fair value of interest rate swaps is calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response: Basic EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
results.json_rows_response:
Basic EPS is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.

results.question: Why did the company exclude certain expenses from their calculation of Adjusted EBITDA?
gold_answer: facilitates comparisons of our operating performance on a period-to-period basis and, in the case of exclusion of acquisition-related expense and certain historical legal expenses, excludes items that we do not consider to be indicative of our core operating performance.

results.csv_string_response: The costs we exclude from our calculation of Adjusted EBITDA are (a) interest income and other income, net; (b) amortization and depreciation expense; (c) stock-based compensation expense; (d) acquisition-related expense; (e) litigation expense; (f) total adjustments; and (g) adjustments for the provision for income taxes. The exclusion of these expenses, which we believe are non-cash charges, allows us to better compare our operating performance to that of other companies in our industry. To the extent that we have other expenses that are not reflected in our calculation of Adjusted EBITDA, those expenses are not included in the computation of Adjusted EBITDA.
results.json_rows_response: Adjusted EBITDA is not a measure that is calculated for all of our activities, as it is for our "core" business, nor is it a measure that is calculated for all of our investments, as it is for our "non-core" business. Adjusted EBITDA excludes certain expenses that we believe are indicative of our core operating performance and should not be included in our GAAP financial results.

results.question: When is revenue recognized?
gold_answer: Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer.

results.question: What are the two forms of revenue generated from contracts with customers?
results.markdown_table_response:
The two forms of revenue generated from contracts with customers are described as follows:
Revenues from sales-based milestones are recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. When determining the transaction price of the contract, an adjustment is made if payment from a customer occurs either significantly before or significantly after performance, resulting in a significant financing component. None of the Company’s licenses and collaboration agreements contained a significant financing component at either December 31, 2019 or 2018.
Revenues from sales royalties are recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation
results.csv_string_response:
The two forms of revenue are:
(1) Sales-based milestones and royalties earned under the license and collaboration agreements for Oxaydo and sales royalties earned under the license for the Nexafed products, are recorded in the period of the related sales by Zyla and MainPointe. Payments of sales-based milestones are generally due within 30 days after the end of a calendar year. Payments of royalties are generally due within 45 days after the end of a calendar quarter.
results.json_rows_response:
Revenue from a contract is recognized when the transaction price is allocated to the performance obligation. If the transaction price is allocated to an obligation that is not performed, then a gain or loss is recognized on the basis of the difference between the transaction price and the estimated standalone selling price of the performance obligation.
The Company’s license and collaboration agreements with Zyla contain a single performance obligation, which is the payment of a license fee. Under the license and collaboration agreement with Zyla, the license fee is based on the option product’s standalone selling price in the option territory. The license fee is therefore recognized in the period in which the standalone selling price of the option product is earned.
The license and collaboration agreements with MainPointe contain multiple performance obligations, which are the payment of a license fee and the payment of royalties. The license fee is based on the standalone selling price of the option product. The license fee is therefore recognized in the period in which the standalone selling price of the option product is earned.

Sales of CTS in 2019 increased 27% to $849.8 million compared to $670.7 million in 2018. The increase was primarily driven by growth in both organic and inorganic business in North America. The increase was primarily due to system development on contracts in New York, Boston, and the San Francisco Bay Area. Businesses acquired by CTS during fiscal year 2019, whose operations are all located in the U.S., had sales of $74.4 million in fiscal year 2019. Sales increased slightly in Australia between fiscal years 2018 and 2019 as increased system development work on a contract in Brisbane was partially offset by the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates as well as a decrease in service sales. Sales were lower in the UK primarily due to a decrease in system development work in London and the negative impact of currency exchange rates. The average exchange rates between the prevailing currencies in our foreign operations and the U.S. dollar resulted in a decrease in CTS sales of $22.2 million for 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the British pound and Australian dollar.
